repnme.cdata!:
Gambia - Poverty Alleviation and Capacity
            Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Poverty Alleviation and
            Capacity Building Project for Gambia were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was significant, the Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: when project objectives focus on directly
            assisting the poor, the project design should facilitate
            identifying the poor clients and their priority needs as
            well as sound monitoring and evaluation (M&E) to monitor
            the progress of poverty alleviation. The Bank is in a good
            position to deploy technical expertise for this purpose in
            the Gambia by drawing from its extensive global experience
            in this area. When municipal technical capacity and
            resources to maintain asphalt roads is limited, sub-project
            investments should consider engineering designs such as
            interlocking paving blocks, which require minimal
            maintenance. Also when Local Government Authority (LGA)
            technical capacity is weak, municipalities need more
            technical assistance and training for staff at all levels.
            Service staff can hone basic technical skills such as those
            needed for maintenance and record keeping, for instance. At
            the leadership level, training of LGA managers and
            councilors can help make them more aware of the need for
            planning and budgeting of municipal services.

            Building Project

repnme.cdata!:
Gambia - Poverty Alleviation and Capacity
            Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Gambia Poverty
            Alleviation and Capacity Building Project were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was low or negligible, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satsifactory. Some lessons learned included: 1) building
            local capacity for delivery of quality works and services is
            a key for the Government, especially in a small country like
            The Gambia with a limited market; 2) Gamworks was
            instrumental in developing a local capacity for contract
            management and improve execution of Bank-financed projects
            and should be further supported; 3) local government
            authorities should pay adequate attention to development of
            technical, managerial and financial capacity and should
            receive further assistance to succeed; and 4) the Project
            has helped local governments to meet some of their priority
            infrastructure needs and significantly improve their
            resource mobilization through strengthening their tax base
            and collection procedures.
